courses.name: General Psychology
courses.description: Survey of theories, principles, and methods in the study of human behavior.

courses.name: General Psychology - Honors
courses.description: Survey of theories, principles, and methods in the study of human behavior.

courses.name: Topics in Psychology - Behavioral Science
courses.description: Organized study of selected topics in psychology.  Particular topic and earnable credit may vary by semester. This course carries behavioral science distribution credit for non-psychology majors.  Repeatable upon consent of department.

courses.name: Topics in Psychology - Honors - Behavioral Science
courses.description: Organized study of selected topics in psychology. Particular topic and earnable credit may vary by semester. This course carries behavioral science distribution credit for non-psychology majors. Repeatable upon consent of department.
courses.prerequisites: Honors eligibility required. This course may be restricted to Undergraduate Psychology Majors during Early Registration

courses.name: Topics in Psychology - Behavioral Science - Honors/Writing Intensive
courses.description: Organized study of selected topics in psychology. Particular topic and earnable credit may vary by semester. This course carries behavioral science distribution credit for non-psychology majors. Repeatable upon consent of department.
courses.prerequisites: Honors eligibility required. This course may be restricted to Undergraduate Psychology Majors during Early Registration

courses.name: Applied Psychology
courses.description: Surveys wide range of applications of psychology. Topics include social issues (prejudice and violence), applications to fields such as business and law, applications for personal improvement (improving memory), and others (sports, health, environment).

courses.name: Orientation to the Psychology Major
courses.description: This course is intended to help students choose the best major for themselves and to provide information on careers available to psychology majors.

courses.name: Topics in Psychology-General
courses.description: Organized study of selected topics in psychology.  Particular topic and earnable credit may vary by semester.  This course may not be used toward behavioral science distribution credit. Repeatable upon consent of department.
courses.prerequisites: May be restricted to Undergraduate Psychology Majors during Early Registration

courses.name: Topics in Psychology-Behavioral Science
courses.description: Organized study of selected topics in psychology.  Particular topic and earnable credit may vary by semester. This course carries behavioral science distribution credit for non-psychology majors.  Repeatable upon consent of department.
courses.prerequisites: This course may be restricted to Undergraduate Psychology Majors during Early Registration

courses.name: Learning, Memory, and Cognition
courses.description: Students will gain an understanding of the fundamental principles of learning, memory and cognition, and will be able to recognize important historical figures and their contributions.  Students will also learn how the principles can be applied to their everyday lives.
courses.prerequisites: This course may be restricted to Undergraduate Psychology Majors during Early Registration

courses.name: Mind, Brain, and Behavior
courses.description: Introduction to the structures and processes of the mind and the nervous system, including the psychobiology of eating, sleeping, emotion, stress and learning. No credit if taken after PSYCH 4210.    Recommended: PSYCH 1000
courses.prerequisites: This course may be restricted to Undergraduate Psychology Majors during Early Registration

courses.name: Drugs and Behavior
courses.description: Basic principles of drug action on the nervous system; the effects of important psychoactive drugs; drug use and society.
courses.prerequisites: This course may be restricted to Undergraduate Psychology Majors during Early Registration

courses.name: Social Psychology
courses.description: An introduction to how people's thoughts, feelings and behaviors are influenced by the actual or imagined thoughts, feelings and behaviors of others.
courses.prerequisites: This course may be restricted to Undergraduate Psychology Majors during Early Registration

courses.name: Introduction to Personality
courses.description: Personality is the scientific study of individual differences (e.g., traits, motives, abilities). This course reviews historical theoretical perspectives as well as current research. Students will have an opportunity to learn about on their own motives and traits.
courses.prerequisites: This course may be restricted to undergraduate psychology majors during Early Registration

courses.name: Consumer Psychology
courses.description: This course surveys how and why we engage in consumer activities and how we are affected by them.  We will survey many areas of psychology as they apply to influencing consumer purchase decisions.  We will also survey research examining the consequences of our consumption behavior.
courses.prerequisites: This course may be restricted to undergraduate psychology majors

courses.name: Developmental Psychology
courses.description: Origins and development of child behavior, emphasizing basic physical, cognitive, affective and social processes, and theory and research rather than application or guidance.  Cannot receive credit for more than one of the following: PSYCH 2410, H_D_FS 2420 or H_D_FS 3420 or ESC_PS 2500.
courses.prerequisites: This course may be restricted to Undergraduate Psychology Majors during Early Registration

courses.name: Developmental Psychology - Honors
courses.description: Origins and development of child behavior, emphasizing basic physical, cognitive, affective and social processes, and theory and research rather than application or guidance. Cannot receive credit for more than one of the following: PSYCH 2410, H_D_FS 2420 or H_D_FS 3420 or ESC_PS 2500.
courses.prerequisites: Honors eligibility required.  This course may be restricted to Undergraduate Psychology Majors during Early Registration

courses.name: Survey of Abnormal Psychology
courses.description: Basic survey of maladaptive human behavior and experience, including personality disorders, alcohol and drug abuse, anxiety and mood disorders, sexual dysfunctions, and thought disorders.
courses.prerequisites: This course may be restricted to Undergraduate Psychology Majors during Early Registration

courses.name: Human Sexuality
courses.description: Survey of research on sexual behavior including sex norms, gender identity, sexual dysfunctions, sexual deviation, homosexuality, and legal aspects of sexual behavior. Attendance at small group discussions may be required at the option of the instructor.
courses.prerequisites: This course may be restricted to Undergraduate Psychology Majors during Early Registration

courses.name: Human-Companion Animal Interaction
courses.description: Exploration of historical and theoretical bases of human-companion animal interaction (HAI), the nature issues, and clinical applications of HAI. Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: May be restricted to Undergraduate Psychology Majors during Early Registration

courses.name: Internship in Psychology
courses.description: Work experience in an organization that is relevant to the psychology major.
courses.prerequisites: must be in good standing and have completed 9 credit hours in psychology; instructor's consent.  Intended for students with freshman or sophomore standing

courses.name: Special Problems in Psychology
courses.description: Research apprenticeship with a faculty member, assisting a faculty member in the development and execution of research. May be repeated to 6 hours maximum.

courses.name: Topics in Psychology-General
courses.description: Organized study of selected topics in psychology.  Particular topic and earnable credit may vary by semester.  This course may not be used toward behavioral science distribution credit. Repeatable upon consent of department.

courses.name: Topics in Psychology-Behavioral Science
courses.description: Organized study of selected topics in psychology.  Particular topic and earnable credit may vary by semester. This course carries behavioral science distribution credit for non-psychology majors.  Repeatable upon consent of department.
courses.prerequisites: PSYCH 1000.  This course may be restricted to Undergraduate Psychology Majors during Early Registration

courses.name: Topics in Psychology-Behavioral Science
courses.description: Organized study of selected topics in psychology.  Particular topic and earnable credit may vary by semester. This course carries behavioral science distribution credit for non-psychology majors.  Repeatable upon consent of department.
courses.prerequisites: PSYCH 1000.  This course may be restricted to Undergraduate Psychology Majors during Early Registration. Honors eligibility required

courses.name: Topics in Psychology-Behavioral Science - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Organized study of selected topics in psychology.  Particular topic and earnable credit may vary by semester. This course carries behavioral science distribution credit for non-psychology majors.  Repeatable upon consent of department.
courses.prerequisites: PSYCH 1000.  This course may be restricted to Undergraduate Psychology Majors during Early Registration

courses.name: Research Methods in Psychology I
courses.description: Introduction to scientific reasoning, assessing validity and reliability in research, and basic research methods.
courses.prerequisites: PSYCH 1000.  This course is restricted to psychology majors with sophomore standing and above

courses.name: Research Methods in Psychology I- Honors
courses.description: Introduction to scientific reasoning, assessing validity and reliability in research, and basic research methods.
courses.prerequisites: PSYCH 1000; Honors eligibility required.  This course is restricted to psychology majors with sophomore standing and above

courses.name: Research Methods in Psychology II
courses.description: Continuation of PSYCH 3010 and required for all further labs in psychology.
courses.prerequisites: MATH 1100 with a grade of C- or better or exemption, and PSYCH 1000, and a grade of C or better in PSYCH 3010 and STAT 1200 or exemption.  This course is restricted to junior and senior psychology majors

courses.name: Research Methods in Psychology II - Honors
courses.description: Continuation of PSYCH 3010 and required for all further labs in psychology.
courses.prerequisites: grade of C or better in PSYCH 3010 and STAT 1200 (or its equivalent). Honors eligibility required.  This course is restricted to junior and senior Psychology majors

courses.name: Theories of Learning
courses.description: Discusses classical issues and theories in learning and conditioning, and considers them in contemporary form.
courses.prerequisites: PSYCH 1000.  This course may be restricted to Undergraduate Psychology Majors during Early Registration

courses.name: Theories of Learning - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Discusses classical issues and theories in learning and conditioning, and considers them in contemporary form.
courses.prerequisites: PSYCH 1000.  This course may be restricted to Undergraduate Psychology Majors during Early Registration

courses.name: Decisions, Values and Choice
courses.description: Survey of factors influencing choices and decisions. Topics include cause and effect decisions, values and ethical considerations, outcome likelihood, biases and heuristics, concept formation, self-control and impulsiveness, and social factors.
courses.prerequisites: PSYCH 1000.  This course may be restricted to Undergraduate Psychology Majors during Early Registration

courses.name: Cognitive Psychology
courses.description: A survey of psychological theory and research on human cognition.
courses.prerequisites: PSYCH 1000.  This course may be restricted to Undergraduate Psychology Majors during Early Registration

courses.name: Human Memory
courses.description: Surveys research on human memory, including basic laboratory studies with normal subjects as well as research on amnesia and other memory impairments, life-span memory development, and the cognitive neuroscience of memory.
courses.prerequisites: PSYCH 1000.  This course may be restricted to Undergraduate Psychology Majors during Early Registration

courses.name: Perception and Thought
courses.description: Covers research on various aspects of mental life: language, problem-solving, decision-making, sensory perception.
courses.prerequisites: PSYCH 1000.  This course may be restricted to Undergraduate Psychology Majors during Early Registration

courses.name: Intergroup Relations
courses.description: Provides an overview of the social psychological literature on stereotyping, prejudice, discrimination, and intergroup relations. Students learn theoretical frameworks and research findings regarding the development and maintenance of intergroup conflict.
courses.prerequisites: PSYCH 1000.  This course may be restricted to Undergraduate Psychology Majors during Early Registration

courses.name: Positive Psychology
courses.description: This course introduces students to the science of positive psychology, including its origin and the historical imbalances it addresses within the broader field of psychology. A wide variety of topics are covered, including happiness, materialism, purpose, flow, courage, humility, positive emotions, curiosity, mindfulness, savoring, gratitude, forgiveness, personal strengths, resilience, and compassion. Psychology majors cannot receive credit for both PSYCH 3350 and ESC_PS 4200.
courses.prerequisites: PSYCH 1000, This course may be restricted to Undergraduate Psychology Majors during early registration

courses.name: Automatic Social Judgments
courses.description: In this course we will survey the area of social psychology dealing with automatic social judgments, including an introduction to the topic, review of techniques used to measure automatic social judgments, and discussion of applications of automatic social judgment research. Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: PSYCH 1000. This course may be restricted to Psychology majors through early registration

courses.name: The Science of Mindfulness
courses.description: To gain breadth and depth in understanding the empirical research on mindfulness and contemplative practices. To do well in the course, students must master the substantive content, psychological methodology, APA-style writing, peer-review, and presentation skills. Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: PSYCH 1000 and a grade of C or better in PSYCH 3010. This course may be restricted to psychology majors through early registration

courses.name: The Science of Mindfulness - Writing Intensive
courses.description: To gain breadth and depth in understanding the empirical research on mindfulness and contemplative practices. To do well in the course, students must master the substantive content, psychological methodology, APA-style writing, peer-review, and presentation skills. Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: PSYCH 1000 and a grade of C or better in PSYCH 3010. This course may be restricted to psychology majors through early registration

courses.name: Cognitive Development in Childhood
courses.description: Theories and research on cognitive development in childhood.
courses.prerequisites: PSYCH 1000.  This course may be restricted to Undergraduate Psychology Majors during Early Registration

courses.name: Social Development in Childhood
courses.description: Overview of children's social and emotional development (infancy-adolescence), includes changes in social domains, impact of social functioning on subsequent development, and influence of interpersonal contexts (e.g., family, peers, community) on children's development.
courses.prerequisites: PSYCH 1000.  This course may be restricted to Undergraduate Psychology Majors during Early Registration

courses.name: Social Development in Childhood - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Overview of children's social and emotional development (infancy-adolescence), includes changes in social domains, impact of social functioning on subsequent development, and influence of interpersonal contexts (e.g., family, peers, community) on children's development.
courses.prerequisites: PSYCH 1000.  This course may be restricted to Undergraduate Psychology Majors during Early Registration

courses.name: Women's Professional Development
courses.description: This class takes a lifespan developmental perspective in regards to understanding challenges in women's professional development. Topics include: perceptions and stereotypes of successful women, division of labor in families (housework versus paid work), motherhood and the work place, social policies for working parents, girls' and boys' interests in STEM professions, and gender and workplace economics (starting salaries, negotiation, the gender pay gap). Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: PSYCH 1000. This course may be restricted to undergraduate psychology majors through early registration

courses.name: Women's Professional Development - Honors
courses.description: This class takes a lifespan developmental perspective in regards to understanding challenges in women's professional development. Topics include: perceptions and stereotypes of successful women, division of labor in families (housework versus paid work), motherhood and the work place, social policies for working parents, girls' and boys' interests in STEM professions, and gender and workplace economics (starting salaries, negotiation, the gender pay gap).  Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: PSYCH 1000; Honors eligibility required. This course may be restricted to undergraduate psychology majors through early registration

courses.name: Introduction to Clinical Psychology
courses.description: Comprehensive survey of the field's historical roots, research methods, concepts of abnormality, assessment and intervention methods; also specialties that constitute clinical psychology.
courses.prerequisites: PSYCH 1000.  This course may be restricted to Undergraduate Psychology Majors during Early Registration

courses.name: Introduction to Clinical Psychology - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Comprehensive survey of the field's historical roots, research methods, concepts of abnormality, assessment and intervention methods; also specialties that constitute clinical psychology.
courses.prerequisites: PSYCH 1000.  This course may be restricted to Undergraduate Psychology Majors during Early Registration

courses.name: Health Psychology
courses.description: A hands-on approach to the study of health psychology including research on a topic of current relevance to the field.
courses.prerequisites: PSYCH 1000.  This course may be restricted to Undergraduate Psychology Majors during Early Registration

courses.name: Individual Differences
courses.description: Surveys individual and group differences.  Contributions of various factors to variations in behavior.

courses.name: Law and Psychological Science
courses.description: This survey course examines the interactions of law and psychology across the justice system.  Emphasis is placed on how psychological research does (and does not) inform important legal issues.  Requirements may include an in-class team debate of relevant controversy in law.
courses.prerequisites: PSYCH 1000.  This course may be restricted to Undergraduate Psychology Majors during Early Registration

courses.name: Sleep and Sleep Disorders
courses.description: This course provides a critical review of the current research on both normal sleep and sleep disorders.

courses.name: African-American Psychology
courses.description: (Same as BL_STU 3100 and ESC_PS 3100). The research, theories and paradigms developed to understand the attitudes, behaviors and psychosocial realities of African-Americans are discussed. Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: PSYCH 1000. This course may be restricted to Undergraduate Psychology Majors through Early Registration

courses.name: Topics in Psychology-General
courses.description: Organized study of selected topics in psychology.  Particular topic and earnable credit may vary by semester.  This course may not be used toward behavioral science distribution credit. Repeatable upon consent of department. Enrollment limited to students who have completed PSYCH 1000.

courses.name: Topics in Psychology-Behavioral Science
courses.description: Organized study of selected topics in psychology.  Particular topic and earnable credit may vary by semester. This course carries behavioral science distribution credit for non-psychology majors.  Repeatable upon consent of department.
courses.prerequisites: PSYCH 1000.  This course may be restricted to Undergraduate Psychology Majors during Early Registration

courses.name: Topics in Psychology-Behavioral Science - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Organized study of selected topics in psychology.  Particular topic and earnable credit may vary by semester. This course carries behavioral science distribution credit for non-psychology majors.  Repeatable upon consent of department.
courses.prerequisites: PSYCH 1000.  This course may be restricted to Undergraduate Psychology Majors during Early Registration

courses.name: Topics in Psychology Capstone
courses.description: Students review, evaluate and conduct research on selected topics in psychology. The particular topic will vary by semester and instructor. Enrollment limited to psychology majors with senior standing who have a grade of C or better in PSYCH 3020. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Topics in Psychology Capstone - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Students review, evaluate and conduct research on selected topics in psychology. The particular topic will vary by semester and instructor. Enrollment limited to psychology majors with senior standing who have a grade of C or better in PSYCH 3020. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Perception
courses.description: Data and contemporary theories of perception in all of the senses, with emphasis on visual and auditory perception.
courses.prerequisites: PSYCH 1000.  This course may be restricted to Undergraduate Psychology Majors during Early Registration

courses.name: Physiological Psychology
courses.description: An introduction to neuroscience with an overview of the relation between the brain and behavior.  Topics include intercellular communication, drugs and reward, emotions and stress psychoimmunology, psychopathology, nervous system development and repair, perception, cognition, learning and memory.
courses.prerequisites: PSYCH 1000.  This course may be restricted to Undergraduate Psychology Majors during Early Registration

courses.name: Animal Learning and Behavior
courses.description: Survey of animal behavior and learning abilities, including topics such as learning, habitat selection, foraging, problem solving, mating, communication, conditioning and memory.
courses.prerequisites: PSYCH 1000.  This course may be restricted to Undergraduate Psychology Majors during Early Registration

courses.name: Cognitive Neuroscience
courses.description: The neural basis of human information processing in memory, attention, perception, imagery, movement, and language.
courses.prerequisites: PSYCH 1000.  This course may be restricted to Undergraduate Psychology Majors during Early Registration

courses.name: Attitude Change
courses.description: Theories, methods, and experimental findings in attitude change research.
courses.prerequisites: PSYCH 1000.  This course may be restricted to Undergraduate Psychology Majors during Early Registration

courses.name: Stereotypes and Prejudice
courses.description: This course provides an overview of theory and research on stereotypes, prejudice, and discrimination from a social-psychological perspective.  Course material comes primarily from textbook and supplementary readings, in addition to videos related to these topics.
courses.prerequisites: PSYCH 1000.  This course may be restricted to Undergraduate Psychology Majors during Early Registration

courses.name: Social Cognition
courses.description: The overarching goal of this course is to provide an overview of current research and theory in social cognition. If there is a running theme to this course, it is in the use of "top down" processes in how we construct an understanding of the world around us. That is, we use our past experiences and memories to interpret new experiences, people and behavior. This fact does not dictate whether that understanding is accurate or not. However, social psychologists have historically been interested in the ways that this process leads to errors or biases in a vast array of human endeavors. This perspective has had a strong impact on the trajectory of social cognition.  Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: PSYCH 1000.  This course may be restricted to undergraduate Psychology majors during early registration

courses.name: Personality Development
courses.description: This course covers the topic of temperament and personality development through the lifespan with particular focus on infancy, childhood, and adolescence.  Coverage includes classic and contemporary theories and classic and contemporary research.
courses.prerequisites: PSYCH 1000.  This course may be restricted to Undergraduate Psychology Majors during Early Registration

courses.name: Sex Differences
courses.description: This course covers the evolution of sex differences and hormonal and environmental influences on their expressions in nonhuman species.  These insights are used to understand human sex differences in mate choices, emotions, development, brain and cognition, and in modern societies.
courses.prerequisites: PSYCH 1000.  This course may be restricted to Undergraduate Psychology Majors during Early Registration

courses.name: Behavior Genetics
courses.description: (cross-leveled with PSYCH 7520). The study of genetic influences on behavioral traits such as mood, personality, intelligence, mental health, or activity level.
courses.prerequisites: PSYCH 1000; Grade of C or better in PSYCH 3010 and STAT 1200 or higher.  This course may be restricted to Undergraduate Psychology Majors during Early Registration

courses.name: Research in Psychopathology
courses.description: Intensive survey and evaluation of the psychological literature on abnormal behavior, emphasizes experimental and explanatory approaches.
courses.prerequisites: PSYCH 1000. This course may be restricted to Undergraduate Psychology Majors during Early Registration

courses.name: Emotional Disorders in Childhood and Adolescence
courses.description: Surveys disturbed behavioral development during childhood and adolescence, emphasizing factors that produce deviation from normal developmental patterns.
courses.prerequisites: PSYCH 1000.  This course may be restricted to Undergraduate Psychology Majors during Early Registration

courses.name: Schizophrenia
courses.description: This course will examine one of the most severe, debilitating, and complex mental disorders.  We will review the major symptoms and clinical features of schizophrenia, explore possible causes of Psychology disorder, and critically assess treatments for the disorder.
courses.prerequisites: PSYCH 1000.  This course may be restricted to Undergraduate Psychology Majors during Early Registration

courses.name: Pediatric Neuropsychology
courses.description: Introduction to the field of pediatric neuropsychology and the study of individuals with early brain dysfunction.  Common central nervous system disorders of childhood (e.g. autism, ADHD, epilepsy) will be discussed.
courses.prerequisites: This course may be restricted to Undergraduate Psychology Majors during Early Registration

courses.name: Externalizing Spectrum Disorders
courses.description: The purpose of this course is to provide an overview of the symptoms, etiology, and treatment of psychiatric disorders that fall within the externalizing spectrum, including Attention-Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder, Oppositional Defiant Disorder, Conduct Disorder, Alcohol and other Substance Use Disorders, and Antisocial Personality Disorder. This course will attempt to provide an overview of key issues and topics related to the classification of psychiatric disorders and how research in this area has led to current conceptualizations of the externalizing spectrum. Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: PSYCH 1000. This course may be restricted to Undergraduate Psychology Majors during Early Registration

courses.name: Autism Mentor Program
courses.description: The Autism Mentor Program and its accompanying course are designed to educate and train student mentors to be of assistance to their peers on the autism spectrum. The student will have an opportunity to participate in class and interact weekly with their mentee in a practical learning environment. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Cross-Cultural Psychology
courses.description: This course aims to explore relationships between cultural variables and human behavior, and to look at recent attempts by cross-cultural psychologists to devise theories that reflect the cultural, social and developmental perspectives on behavior.
courses.prerequisites: PSYCH 1000.  This course is restricted to juniors and seniors

courses.name: Cross-Cultural Psychology - Honors
courses.description: The Cross-cultural Psychology course aims to explore relationships between cultural variables and human behavior, and to look at recent attempts by cross-cultural psychologists to devise theories that reflect the cultural, social and developmental perspectives on behavior.
courses.prerequisites: PSYCH 1000; Honors eligibility required. Restricted to sophomores and above

courses.name: Psychology at the Movies
courses.description: In this course we watch and discuss films from multiple psychological perspectives.  Connections are made between cinematic content and contemporary psychological research on culture and diversity.  Race, Gender, Disability, Class, and LGBT issues in movies are explored.
courses.prerequisites: PSYCH 1000. Restricted to juniors and seniors

courses.name: Psychology of Women
courses.description: (same as WGST 4830).   Overview of current theories and research relating to the psychology of women.  Topics include gender stereotyping, psychological sex differences, achievement motivation in women, and women and mental health.

courses.name: The History of Psychology
courses.description: Historical foundations of contemporary psychology.
courses.prerequisites: PSYCH 1000.  This course may be restricted to Undergraduate Psychology Majors during Early Registration

courses.name: Internship in Psychology
courses.description: Work experience in an organization that is relevant to the psychology major.  Enrollment limited to students who are in good standing and have completed 9 credit hours in psychology.  Intended for students with junior or senior standing.

courses.name: Internship in Psychology - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Work experience in an organization that is relevant to the psychology major.  Enrollment limited to students who are in good standing and have completed 9 credit hours in psychology.  Intended for students with junior or senior standing.

courses.name: Special Problems in Psychology
courses.description: Independent investigation leading to a project or paper. Repeatable upon consent of department.

courses.name: Special Readings in Psychology
courses.description: Independent readings selected in consultation with supervisory faculty member. Repeatable upon consent of department.

courses.name: Psychological Measurement Capstone
courses.description: Survey of theories and methods of psychological test construction, focusing on measures of intelligence and personality. Lab component involves experimental training in test construction and test evaluation.
courses.prerequisites: Grade of C or better in PSYCH 3020.  This course is restricted to psychology majors with senior standing. Consent required

courses.name: Developmental Psychology Capstone
courses.description: Introduces students to developmental research methods through relevant readings and by students conducting original research. Enrollment limited to psychology majors with senior standing who have a grade of C or better in PSYCH 3020.

courses.name: Developmental Psychology Capstone - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Introduces students to developmental research methods through relevant readings and by students conducting original research. Enrollment limited to psychology majors with senior standing who have a grade of C or better in PSYCH 3020.

courses.name: Animal Learning Capstone
courses.description: Survey of principles of animal behavior and animal learning and cognition. The course includes laboratory projects on research in animal behavior and animal learning. Enrollment limited to psychology majors with senior standing who have a grade of C or better in PSYCH 3020.

courses.name: Animal Learning Capstone - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Survey of principles of animal behavior and animal learning and cognition. The course includes laboratory projects on research in animal behavior and animal learning. Enrollment limited to psychology majors with senior standing who have a grade of C or better in PSYCH 3020.

courses.name: Human Cognition Capstone
courses.description: Students review, evaluate and conduct research on various aspects of human cognition. Enrollment limited to psychology majors with senior standing who have a grade of C or better in PSYCH 3020.

courses.name: Human Cognition Capstone - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Students review, evaluate and conduct research on various aspects of human cognition. Enrollment limited to psychology majors with senior standing who have a grade of C or better in PSYCH 3020.

courses.name: The Human Senses Capstone
courses.description: Psychophysical data, sense organs, psychological attributes, and theories of vision, hearing, and the vestibular (motion) senses. Elementary aspects of psychophysics.
courses.prerequisites: grade of C better in PSYCH 3020.  This course is restricted to psychology majors with senior standing. Department Consent

courses.name: The Human Senses Capstone - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Psychophysical data, sense organs, psychological attributes, and theories of vision, hearing, and the vestibular (motion) senses. Elementary aspects of psychophysics.
courses.prerequisites: grade of C better in PSYCH 3020.  This course is restricted to psychology majors with senior standing. Consent required

courses.name: Social/Personality Capstone
courses.description: Experimental methods course emphasizing research in social psychology.  Enrollment limited to psychology majors with senior standing who have a grade of C or better in PSYCH 3020.

courses.name: Social/Personality Capstone - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Experimental methods course emphasizing research in social psychology.  Enrollment limited to psychology majors with senior standing who have a grade of C or better in PSYCH 3020.

courses.name: Independent Research Capstone I
courses.description: Individual thesis on a topic selected with a faculty advisor. Student projects are carried out over the course of two semesters (with PSYCH 4977) and presented as posters in a spring conference. Weekly class discussions of student progress.  For students who plan to pursue a PhD in Psychology or Neuroscience. Enrollment limited to psychology majors with senior standing who have taken PSYCH 3020.

courses.name: Honors Research Capstone I
courses.description: Individual thesis on a topic selected with a faculty advisor. Student projects are carried out over the course of two semesters (with PSYCH 4977H) and presented as posters in a spring conference. Weekly class discussions of student progress. For students who plan to pursue a PhD in Psychology or Neuroscience. Enrollment limited to psychology majors with senior standing, honors eligibility, a cumulative GPA of 3.5, who have taken PSYCH 3020.

courses.name: Honors Research Capstone I - Honors/Writing Intensive
courses.description: Individual thesis on a topic selected with a faculty advisor. Student projects are carried out over the course of two semesters (with PSYCH 4977HW) and presented as posters in a spring conference. Weekly class discussions of student progress. For students who plan to pursue a PhD in Psychology or Neuroscience. Enrollment limited to psychology majors with senior standing, honors eligibility, a cumulative GPA of 3.5, who have taken PSYCH 3020.

courses.name: Independent Research Capstone I - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Individual thesis on a topic selected with a faculty advisor. Student projects are carried out over the course of two semesters (with PSYCH 4977W) and presented as posters in a spring conference. Weekly class discussions of student progress.  For students who plan to pursue a PhD in Psychology or Neuroscience. Enrollment limited to psychology majors with senior standing who have taken PSYCH 3020.

courses.name: Independent Research Capstone II
courses.description: Continuation of PSYCH 4976. Completion of research project, presentation of poster in a spring conference. Weekly class discussions of student progress. Enrollment limited to psychology majors with senior standing who have completed PSYCH 4976.

courses.name: Honors Research Capstone II
courses.description: Continuation of PSYCH 4976H. Completion of research project, presentation of poster in a spring conference. Weekly class discussions of student progress.  Enrollment limited to psychology majors with senior standing, honors eligibility, a cumulative GPA of 3.5, who have completed PSYCH 4976H.

courses.name: Honors Research Capstone II - Honors/Writing Intensive
courses.description: Continuation of PSYCH 4976HW. Completion of research project, presentation of poster in a spring conference. Weekly class discussions of student progress.  Enrollment limited to psychology majors with senior standing, honors eligibility, a cumulative GPA of 3.5, who have completed PSYCH 4976HW.

courses.name: Independent Research Capstone II - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Continuation of PSYCH 4976W. Completion of research project, presentation of poster in a spring conference. Weekly class discussions of student progress. Enrollment limited to psychology majors with senior standing who have completed PSYCH 4976W.

courses.name: Clinical Psychology Capstone
courses.description: Students work at assigned agencies to gain "real-world" experience in the practice of psychology and attend regularly scheduled class meetings in order to integrate their academic knowledge with their practical experience.  Enrollment limited to psychology majors with senior standing who have a grade of C or better in PSYCH 3020.

courses.name: Clinical Psychology Capstone - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Students work at assigned agencies to gain "real-world" experience in the practice of psychology and attend regularly scheduled class meetings in order to integrate their academic knowledge with their practical experience.  Enrollment limited to psychology majors with senior standing who have a grade of C or better in PSYCH 3020.

courses.name: Judgement and Decision Making Capstone
courses.description: This course examines the psychology of human judgement and decision-making.  We will discuss major theories, methods and basic experimental findings and identify how those findings are being used to develop public policy or in applied settings.
courses.prerequisites: grade of C or better in PSYCH 2030; This course is restricted to psychology majors with senior standing. Consent required

courses.name: Judgement and Decision Making Capstone - Writing Intensive
courses.description: This course examines the psychology of human judgement and decision-making.  We will discuss major theories, methods and basic experimental findings and identify how those findings are being used to develop public policy or in applied settings.
courses.prerequisites: grade of C or better in PSYCH 2030; This course is restricted to psychology majors with senior standing. Consent required

courses.name: Human Relationships Capstone
courses.description: Students design a study, collect data, and describe their research on some aspect of human relationships.  Emphasis on survey research techniques.  Enrollment limited to psychology majors with senior standing, a grade of C or better in PSYCH 3020, PSYCH 2810 or two social/personality courses.

courses.name: Human Relationships Capstone - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Students design a study, collect data, and describe their research on some aspect of human relationships.  Emphasis on survey research techniques.  Enrollment limited to psychology majors with senior standing, a grade of C or better in PSYCH 3020, PSYCH 2810 or two social/personality courses.

courses.name: Advanced Developmental Psychology Capstone I
courses.description: Students propose a study to be conducted with preschool children.  The course teaches skills needed to develop research questions, develop a coding system, and write a research proposal that reviews past literature in a way that makes the case for the importance of the project. Graded on A-F basis only.  Enrollment limited to psychology majors with senior standing and a grade of C or better in PSYCH 3020.

courses.name: Advanced Developmental Psychology Capstone I - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Students propose a study to be conducted with preschool children.  The course teaches skills needed to develop research questions, develop a coding system, and write a research proposal that reviews past literature in a way that makes the case for the importance of the project. Graded on A-F basis only.  Enrollment limited to psychology majors with senior standing and a grade of C or better in PSYCH 3020.

courses.name: Advanced Developmental Psychology II
courses.description: Students conduct a research project involving observations of preschool children.  The course teaches skills needed to collect data, analyze data, and write a research report.  These skills provide excellent preparation for graduate school in psychology or a related field. Graded on A-F basis only.  Enrollment limited to psychology majors with senior standing who have a grade of C or better in PSYCH 3020.

courses.name: Advanced Developmental Psychology II - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Students conduct a research project involving observations of preschool children.  The course teaches skills needed to collect data, analyze data, and write a research report.  These skills provide excellent preparation for graduate school in psychology or a related field. Graded on A-F basis only.  Enrollment limited to psychology majors with senior standing who have a grade of C or better in PSYCH 3020.

courses.name: Consumer Psychology Capstone
courses.description: This course examines numerous social and psychological issues related to the area of consumer psychology. The course begins by examining how media exposure influences consumption, prejudice in marketing and advertising, and the question of whether children should be targets of marketing strategies. The second section examines how consumption can be influenced by unconscious and automatic factors. The third section examines unhealthy forms of consumption and consumption's relationship to well being. The fourth section focuses on ethical and social responsibility issues like consumption's impact on the environment and the voluntary simplicity movement. The last section of the course is devoted to student presentations of term papers.  Graded on A-F basis only.  Enrollment limited to psychology majors with senior standing who have a grade of C or better in PSYCH 3020.

courses.name: Consumer Psychology Capstone - Writing Intensive
courses.description: This course examines numerous social and psychological issues related to the area of consumer psychology. The course begins by examining how media exposure influences consumption, prejudice in marketing and advertising, and the question of whether children should be targets of marketing strategies. The second section examines how consumption can be influenced by unconscious and automatic factors. The third section examines unhealthy forms of consumption and consumption's relationship to well being. The fourth section focuses on ethical and social responsibility issues like consumption's impact on the environment and the voluntary simplicity movement. The last section of the course is devoted to student presentations of term papers.  Graded on A-F basis only.  Enrollment limited to psychology majors with senior standing who have a grade of C or better in PSYCH 3020.

courses.name: Promoting Social Justice, Diversity, and Inclusion Capstone
courses.description: This course is an advanced exploration of diversity and social justice in the United States and provides students with a framework for understanding specific forms and the interlocking systems of oppression; a process to explore how oppression affects our lives; a pedagogical framework for teaching and training about concepts of oppression and diversity; and an application of these ideologies and skills in community settings. Enrollment limited to psychology majors with senior standing who have a grade of C or better in PSYCH 3020. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Topics in Psychology - General
courses.description: Organized study of selected topics in psychology.  Particular topic and earnable credit may vary by semester.  Graduate credit will be earned through additional reading and assignments.
courses.prerequisites: instructor's consent; departmental consent for repetition

courses.name: Topics in Psychology - Behavioral Science
courses.description: Organized study of selected topics in psychology.  Particular topic and earnable credit may vary by semester.  Graduate credit will be earned through additional reading and assignments.
courses.prerequisites: instructor's consent; departmental consent for repetition

courses.name: Problems in Psychology
courses.description: Advanced studies to meet needs of individual student. Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Perception
courses.description: (cross-leveled with PSYCH 4110). Data and contemporary theories of perception in all of the senses, with emphasis on visual and auditory perception.

courses.name: Physiological Psychology
courses.description: An introduction to neuroscience giving an overview of the relation between the brain and behavior.  Topics include intercellular communication, drugs and reward, emotions and stress psychoimmunology, psychopathology, nervous system development and repair, perception, cognition, learning and memory.

courses.name: Attitude Change
courses.description: Theories, methods, and experimental findings in attitude change research.

courses.name: Personality Development
courses.description: This course covers the topic of temperament and personality development through the lifespan with particular focus on infancy, childhood, and adolescence.  Coverage includes classic and contemporary theories and classic and contemporary research.

courses.name: Behavior Genetics
courses.description: (cross-leveled with PSYCH 4520). The study of genetic influences on behavioral traits such as mood, personality, intelligence, mental health, or activity level.

courses.name: Research in Psychopathology
courses.description: Intensive survey and evaluation of the psychological literature on abnormal behavior, emphasizes experimental and explanatory approaches.

courses.name: Introduction to Clinical Psychology
courses.description: Comprehensive survey of the field's historical roots, research methods, concepts of abnormality, assessment and intervention methods; also specialties that constitute clinical psychology.

courses.name: Schizophrenia
courses.description: Examines symptoms, possible causes, and treatments of schizophrenia.  Goals include understanding psychopathology by examining one disorder and reviewing cutting edge psychology and clinical science research being used to understand schizophrenia.

courses.name: Industrial/Organizational Psychology
courses.description: Survey of basic and applied personnel and organizational psychology. Focus on the human relations field, job satisfaction, leadership, group dynamics and formal organizational structures within the realm of industry.

courses.name: Cross-Cultural Psychology
courses.description: This course aims to explore relationships between cultural variables and human behavior, and to look at recent attempts by cross-cultural psychologists to devise theories that reflect the cultural, social and developmental perspectives on behavior.

courses.name: Psychology of Women
courses.description: Overview of current theories and research relating to the psychology of women. Topics include gender stereotyping, psychological sex differences, achievement motivation in women, and women and mental health.

courses.name: The History of Psychology
courses.description: Historical foundations of contemporary psychology.

courses.name: Topics in Psychology-General
courses.description: Organized study of selected topics in psychology. Particular topic and earnable credit may vary by semester.
courses.prerequisites: instructor's consent, departmental consent for repetition

courses.name: Research in Psychology - Non-Thesis
courses.description: Research in psychology not leading to thesis.  Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Problems in Psychology
courses.description: Advanced studies to meet needs of individual student. Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Research in Psychology - Thesis
courses.description: Research in psychology leading to thesis.  Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Cognitive Psychology
courses.description: Focuses on basic research on human perception, memory, attention, language, and thought.

courses.name: Functional Neuroscience
courses.description: Basic techniques, data and theory in the neurosciences applied to the study of psychopathology, psychopharmacology, neural development, brain damage, memory and other areas of "behavior."

courses.name: Survey of Social Psychology
courses.description: Survey of historical and contemporary theory and research in affiliation, attribution, social comparison, attitude change and group dynamics.

courses.name: Psychology of Development
courses.description: Principles, theories, research in normal human development.

courses.name: Cognitive Development
courses.description: (same as H D FS 8420). An introduction to central theories and issues in the study of cognitive development in infancy and childhood. Emphasis is on major theoretical frameworks for studying cognitive development, and topics such as perception, memory, language, categorization, and reasoning.

courses.name: Temperament and Personality Development
courses.description: (same as H_D_FS 8430). Intended for graduate students in psychology and related fields.  This course is a survey of theory and research in the area of temperament and personality development, with emphasis on child development.

courses.name: Social and Emotional Development
courses.description: (same as H_D_FS 8440). There are two major objectives for this course.  The first is a "content" objective and involves familiarizing students with theory and research regarding social, emotional, and personality development in childhood and adolescence and also regarding the relationships in which such development takes place.  The second objective is a "process" objective and involves enhancing students skills at interpreting empirical research, identifying gaps in the literature, and identifying research strategies for addressing those gaps.

courses.name: Developmental Psychopathology
courses.description: Etiology, diagnosis, and treatment of disordered behavior from infancy through adolescence. Emphasizes contrasting theories and research issues.

courses.name: Adult Psychopathology
courses.description: Problems of etiology, diagnosis, treatment in psychopathology. Considers theory, research, case histories.

courses.name: Experimental Psychopathology
courses.description: Critical examination of current theories, with special emphasis on empirical studies in psychopathology including such topics as alcoholism, enuresis, sexual deviancy, drug addiction, mental retardation.

courses.name: Motivation
courses.description: Survey of historical and contemporary theories and models of human motivation.  Major emphasis on different levels of motivational analysis.

courses.name: Personality Psychology
courses.description: Graduate-level introduction to the field of personality psychology, including readings and discussion of both classic and contemporary works.

courses.name: General Linear Models in Psychology I
courses.description: Principles of interval estimation and hypothesis testing, scalar and matrix forms of simple and multiple regression with continuous and categorical predictors, regression diagnostics.
courses.prerequisites: undergraduate course in statistics; concurrent enrollment in PSYCH 8730; instructor's consent

courses.name: General Linear Models in Psychology II
courses.description: Complex analysis of variance; experimental design.
courses.prerequisites: PSYCH 8710 or equivalent, concurrent enrollment in PSYCH 8730; instructor's consent

courses.name: Statistical Software Packages
courses.description: Computer implementation of data management and statistical analysis. Covers elementary computer operations, data entry and quality control, and computer implementation of statistical models covered in PSYCH 8710 and PSYCH 8720.

courses.name: Responsible Conduct of Research
courses.description: This course exposes students to important concepts in the responsible conduct of research. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Social and Behavioral Sciences in Public Health
courses.description: (same as P_HLTH 8920). This course will take both a theoretical and a practical approach to understanding health-related behavior and the field of public health.  Students will gain an understanding of theory and empirical research in the social and behavioral sciences, as well as developing practical skills in critically evaluating research and in applying scientific evidence to address real world health concerns.

courses.name: Topics in Psychology-General
courses.description: Organized study of selected topics in psychology. Particular topic and earnable credit may vary by semester.
courses.prerequisites: instructor's consent, departmental consent for repetition

courses.name: Research in Psychology - Non-Dissertation
courses.description: Research in Psychology not leading to dissertation. Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Problems in Psychology
courses.description: Advanced studies to meet needs of individual student. Graded on S/U basis only.
courses.prerequisites: instructor's consent.  Departmental consent for repetition

courses.name: Research in Psychology - Dissertation
courses.description: Research in Psychology leading to dissertation.  Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Studies in Experimental Psychology
courses.description: Critical consideration of selected research in neuroscience and cognitive psychology.
courses.prerequisites: PSYCH 4972 or PSYCH 4973; departmental consent for repetition; instructor's consent

courses.name: Studies in Physiological Psychology
courses.description: Weekly seminars given by local and regional cognitive psychologists and cognitive neuroscientists.  Graded on S/U basis only.
courses.prerequisites: PSYCH 7210, departmental consent for repetition, and instructor's consent

courses.name: Human Learning and Memory
courses.description: Current theory and research in the area of human learning and memory will be investigated. A major component of the course will involve the critical review of existing literature in this area.

courses.name: Psychopharmacology
courses.description: Basic principles of drug action on the nervous system, the theory and clinical use of the various psychotherapeutic drugs, drug abuse and its treatment.

courses.name: Clinical Neuropsychology Seminar
courses.description: In this course students will analyze published cases in the neuropsychology literature.  By studying how behavioral and mental processes break down, the supposition is that one can infer how intact processes must have been constructed, and how a brain supports them.

courses.name: Seminar on fMRI
courses.description: Fundamentals of MRI and its application to brain imaging, including experimental design, analysis and contemporary issues.  During the lab component, students will use FSL and other software to analyze fMRI data and will design and implement their own fMRI experiments.

courses.name: Advanced Neural Systems
courses.description: The course provides in-depth coverage of the neurophysiology, neuroanatomy, and function of the brain. Course lectures and discussions cover the brain and its systems in a "bottom-up" sequence starting with basic sensory pathways and concluding with higher cognitive functions. The course also includes hands-on laboratory sessions, which include dissection component. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Theories of Social Psychology
courses.description: Intensive review of classic and contemporary concepts and theories of social psychology; emphasizes readings from primary sources. PhD candidates only. Required for all PhD candidates in social psychology.

courses.name: Social Psychology Methodology
courses.description: Advanced study of experimental methods in social psychological research.

courses.name: Field Research Methods
courses.description: Advanced course in research methods and designs commonly used in field settings; theoretical, ethical, and pragmatic issues that arise in field settings are considered; emphasis is on learning and skill acquisition through a series of hands-on assignments.

courses.name: Studies in Social Psychology
courses.description: Critical coverage of selected research and theory in social psychology.
courses.prerequisites: instructor's consent, departmental consent for repetition

courses.name: Seminar in Social Psychology
courses.description: Intensive review of concepts and theories of social psychology; emphasizes readings from primary sources. Ph.D. candidates only. Required for all Ph.D. candidates in social psychology program. Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Positive Psychology
courses.description: This seminar will discuss and critique modern research in positive psychology. Each chapter of the textbook provides overviews of positive psychology research topics at various levels of analysis, while providing suggestions for further research. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Studies in Developmental Psychology
courses.description: Covers contemporary research and professional topics in developmental psychology. Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Studies in Evolution and Behavior
courses.description: Reading and discussion of classic and contemporary works in evolution.

courses.name: Women's Professional Development
courses.description: This class takes a lifespan developmental perspective in regards to understanding challenges in women's professional development. Topics include: perceptions and stereotypes of successful women, division of labor in families (housework versus paid work), motherhood and the work place, social policies for working parents, girls' and boys' interests in STEM professions, and gender and workplace economics (starting salaries, negotiation, the gender pay gap).  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Studies in Clinical Psychology
courses.description: Contemporary research and theory for advanced graduate students in clinical psychology. Graded on S/U basis only.
courses.prerequisites: instructor's consent, departmental consent for repetition

courses.name: Orientations in Psychotherapy
courses.description: The introductory psychotherapy course for students in the clinical psychology doctoral program.  The focus of the course is on development of knowledge and skills in the following four areas: (1) Theory and practice of contemporary (brief) psychotherapy; (2) Basic interviewing skills; (3) Psychotherapy research and empirically supported treatments; and (4) The role and impact of managed care in contemporary psychotherapy.

courses.name: Psychometrics
courses.description: Introduction to concepts and issues essential to psychological assessment including psychometrics, test construction, controversies in psychological testing, behavioral assessment, and structured interviewing.

courses.name: Orientations to Clinical Assessment
courses.description: Topics include psychometric principles, intelligence testing, objective and projective personality testing and behavioral assessment.

courses.name: Clinical Child Assessment
courses.description: Introduction to clinical instruments, techniques and problems in the psychological assessment of children.

courses.name: Ethical and Professional Issues II
courses.description: Legal issues, state and national codes, ethical decision-making, dangerousness, ethical clinical treatment issues, mandated reporting, and ethics in specialized clinical settings.  This course is the second in a sequence for clinical psychology doctoral students.

courses.name: Clinical Practicum
courses.description: Intensive supervised training in use and interpretation of psychological techniques and in psychotherapy. Graded on S/U basis only.
courses.prerequisites: instructor's consent and professional liability insurance

courses.name: Clinical Intervention with Children
courses.description: Introduction to theory, research and practice in the area of behavior change with children and adolescents.

courses.name: Family and Group Process
courses.description: Theory, intervention, and research in the areas of family and group dynamics.  Emphasis on family therapy approaches.

courses.name: Assessment and Treatment of Sexual Problems
courses.description: Background information for and methods and techniques of dealing with a variety of sexual problems that clients bring to therapists. Sexual dysfunction, homosexuality, sexual aberrations and sex crimes covered.

courses.name: Clinical Research Methods
courses.description: Focus on research design with emphasis on active critique of methodological challenges (e.g., subject selection, control groups, multimodal measures, and treatment issues), includes lecture and active review or research.

courses.name: Seminar in Clinical Psychology
courses.description: Critical coverage of selected research and theory in clinical psychology.
courses.prerequisites: instructor's consent, departmental consent for repetition

courses.name: Introduction to Alcohol Studies
courses.description: Intensive seminar on alcohol research primarily intended for alcohol research training fellows.  Covers a range of topics of interest to psychologist, including pharmacology, research methods, genetics, diagnosis, expectancies, and treatment.

courses.name: Clinical Pediatric Neuropsychology
courses.description: The goal of this course is to provide an in-depth introduction to the field of clinical pediatric neuropsychology.  Particular emphasis will be placed on how we can increase our understanding of development through the study of individuals with early brain dysfunction.

courses.name: Multivariate Statistics in Psychology
courses.description: Multivariate statistical methods, including multivariate analysis of variance, discriminant analysis, principal component analysis, and elements of matrix algebra, as applied to problems in psychology.

courses.name: Multilevel Modeling
courses.description: Introduction to random coefficient multilevel modeling of clustered data. Topics include two- and three-level models, estimation techniques, computing options, model fitting issues, advanced model applications, and growth modeling.
courses.prerequisites: instructor's consent, a graduate course in regression analysis

courses.name: Latent Variable Models in Statistical Analysis
courses.description: Covers Matrix Algebra fundamentals, Factor Rotation, Communality Estimation techniques, High Order and Dynamic Factor Models, Path Analysis, Use of computer programs.

courses.name: The Literature Review
courses.description: Focuses on methods for gathering, summarizing, integrating and interpreting research on a particular research issue. Topics include searching the literature, evaluating research quality and synthesizing statistical results across separate studies.

courses.name: Psychological Process Models
courses.description: Examines mathematical and statistical models of cognition and perception.  Emphasis on modeling basics such as estimation, hypothesis testing, and assessment of fit.
courses.prerequisites: PSYCH 8710 and PSYCH 8720 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Statistical Consulting for Psychologists
courses.description: Provision of statistical consulting to individuals working with psychological data.  Graded on S/U basis only.
courses.prerequisites: graduate standing in Psychological Sciences and instructor's consent

courses.name: Advanced Structural Equation Modeling
courses.description: Growth Mixture Models, Dynamic Factor models, and nonlinear structural models.

courses.name: Quantitative Psychology Seminar
courses.description: Quantitative Psychology Topics Seminar. Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Categorical Data Analysis
courses.description: This course will provide an applied introduction to the most important methods for analyzing categorical data.  Topics include; logistic regression modeling Poisson regression modeling, multinomial sampling, and classic analysis of contingency tables.

courses.name: Cluster Analysis and Network Analysis
courses.description: The course covers traditional and modern clustering techniques (hierarchical, partitioning, and mixture modeling), both from an algorithmic and modeling perspective. Several types of data types are explored, including traditional two-mode data sets and network structures.

courses.name: Item Response Theory I
courses.description: Introduction to item response theory, including classical test theory, popular item response models, model estimation, software considerations, and application. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Teaching of Psychology Practicum
courses.description: Focuses on development and enhancement of teaching skills for graduate students in psychology who are primary instructors of undergraduate psychology courses. Graded on a S/U basis only.

courses.name: Advanced History of Psychology
courses.description: Advanced course in history of psychology designed to show how general philosophical models of mind and behavior have been linked to doctrines of mental health and pathology and to theories of social behavior.
